details.title: Accelerated degradation-tests with tightened critical values

authors.affiliation: Ford Motor Co., Dearborn, MI, USA

p: Guangbin Yang is a reliability engineer at the Ford Motor Company. He had worked, previously, for years at the Yazaki North America, Visteon Automotive Systems, and China Electronic Product Reliability and Environmental Testing Research Institute. In 2000, he received his Ph.D. in industrial engineering from Wayne State University, and his M.S. and B.S. in 1989 and 1986, respectively, in mechanical engineering from Zhejiang University and Hangzhou Institute of Electronic Engineering. His work and publications are mainly in the development and deployment of methods and tools for reliability design, test, and data analysis. He organized and chaired the invited sessions for the ISSAT Conference on “Reliability and Quality in Design.” Dr. Yang is a Senior Member of the IEEE and ASQ. He is listed in Who's Who in America, Who's Who in Science and Engineering, and Who's Who in the World.

authors.name: Guangbin Yang

p: Kai Yang is an Associate Professor in the Department of Industrial and Manufacturing Engineering, Wayne State University. He received both the M.S. and Ph.D. in industrial and operations research engineering at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. Dr. Yang has been doing active research in quality and reliability engineering since he joined Wayne State. Dr. Yang is a Senior Member of IIE, member of ASQ, IEEE INFORMS, and the American Statistical Association.

details.abstract: ALT (accelerated life tests) are widely used to provide quickly the information about life distributions of products. Life data at elevated stresses are extrapolated to estimate the life distribution at design stress. The existing estimation methods are efficient and easy to implement-given sufficient life data. However, ALT frequently results in few or no failures at low-level stress, making it difficult to estimate the life distribution. For products whose failures are defined in terms of performance characteristics exceeding their critical values, reliability assessment can be based on degradation measurements by using degradation models. The estimation, however, is usually mathematically complicated and computationally intensive. This paper presents a method for the estimation of life distribution by using life data from degradation measurements. Since the time-to-failure depends on the level of a critical value, more life data can be obtained by tightening the critical value. The relationship between life and critical value and stress is modeled and used to estimate the life distribution at a usual critical value and design stress. The model parameters are estimated by using maximum likelihood. The optimum test plans, which choose the critical values, stress levels, and proportions of sample size to each stress level, are devised by minimizing the asymptotic variance of the mean (log) life at a usual critical value and design stress. The comparison between the proposed and existing 2-level test plans shows that the proposed plans have smaller asymptotic variance and are less sensitive to the uncertainty of the pre-estimates of unknown parameters.

context.text: Various efficient methods for the estimation have been developed and are fairly easy to implement [1].

references.title: Statistical inference of a time-to-failure distribution derived from linear degradation data

context.text: Life distributions are estimated by using degradation models which relate the degradation measurements to aging time [2]–[3][5].
The estimation, however, is mathematically complicated and computationally laborious, even if the degradation model is linear in parameters [3].

For some products, the degradation paths take the linear form [3], [7]:

\$\alpha_{l,\,k}\$

\$\equiv\$ degradation path parameters for \$l = 0,\, 1,\, 2\$


\$\epsilon_{i,\,k}(t)\$

\$\equiv\$ measurement error.

references.title: Optimum constant-stress accelerated life-test plans

context.text: Generally, \$\mu(1,\,1)\$ can be approximated by using experience, similar data, and/or a reliability prediction handbook like [9]. \$\mu(0,\,0) , \ \mu(0,\,1) , \ \sigma\$ can be pre-estimated by using a preliminary ADT conducted at the highest level of stress.

links.abstract: This paper deals with optimal design of four-level constant-stress accelerated life test plans with various censoring times. The optimum plans choose the stress levels, test units allocated to each stress, and censoring times to minimize the asymptotic variance of the MLE of the mean (log) life at design stress and test length. A FORTRAN-77 program was written to calculate the optimum plan. This paper compares the test plans with existing three-level test plans, and concludes that: the mean numb...

references.text: G. Yang, "Optimum constant-stress accelerated life-test plans", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 43, no. 4, pp. 575-581, Dec. 1994.

references.title: Optimum censored accelerated life tests for normal and lognormal life distributions

context.text: test plans developed by Kielpinski and Nelson [10].

links.abstract: This paper presents optimum accelerated life test plans for estimating a simple linear relationship between a stress and the median of product life which has a s-normal or lognormal distribution when the data are analyzed before all test units fail. Also, plans with equal numbers of test units at equally spaced test stresses are compared with the optimum plans. The plans are illustrated with a temperature-accelerated life test of electrical insulation.

references.text: T. Kielpinski, W. Nelson, "Optimum censored accelerated life tests for normal and lognormal life distributions", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-24, no. 5, pp. 310-320, 1975.
